Social Media are not going to make the world a better place. The revolution will not be televised or take place on Tiktok, WhatsApp, Twitter, FB, etc, but SM are one way in which human beings can stay in touch in a world that does not otherwise make it easy.

For people whose real life social contact is limited by distance, peripherality, age, infirmity, transport or pandemic, a chat on FB can be a whole lot better than nothing at all. Which is the alternative for many.

I share stuff about Folk Clubs & gigs on FB. Also pics of my garden, & other people's paintings. Most villages round here have a FB page that shares info about lost pets, playground equipment, fallen trees and sales of obscure objects. All fairly superficial, yes, but useful.

I hear about articles, books & blogs from people like @TuffreyWijne @chrishattoncedr @trishgreenhalgh @TommyShakes @RoseUnwin @ellen_hawley on twitter. These are interesting, useful & even funny. I'd need to read a lot more journals & newsletters to get similar level of info.

I stay in touch with people like you & my nephew, @PaulbernalUK via twitter. His siblings, children of my parents friends, parents of my children's friends, old school mates via FB. Realistically though we could write, e-mail, phone, we are all busy people - we probably wouldn't.

No need to apologise, is there? All social media waste our time & treat us as ore to be mined on behalf of the advertisers & dodgy political influencers who are their real customers. On the other hand we get something in return for our privacy. https://t.co/2bhuyGslNp

That means good enough managers,, just asked need good enough cleaners, porters, clerical staff, radiographers, physios, doctors,nurses & all the other 'front-line' staff. Cherish the good ones.

Many are ex-clinicians & some still have a clinical role. Our NHS needs practice and ward managers; complaints departments; payroll; people who know how to write a business case for a new building or piece of kit; & Senior managers to wrestle with Government, & manage crises.

They sit in an unenviable position between the rest of the workforce the orders & targets set by NHS-England/Improvement. They must allocate, usually inadequate, money between competing groups of clinicians, each, usually, convinced that their bid will benefit their patients.

Name me another large industry that does not need managers. NHS more complex than most. I've worked with some brilliant & some awful managers, but they definitely have a job to do. Most went into NHS hoping to help people. https://t.co/QXNWOojtnZ

Also about recognising that those pesky "underlying conditions" are best though of as risk factors, indicating a need to look/listen more carefully & try to get to effective treatment, if that is what person wants, sooner.

It is about communication skills: allowing & being allowed time in consultation; health professionals knowing how to listen to disabled people, paid & family carers; avoiding diagnostic overshadowing & other pitfalls.

What is worrying me is that the crisis in access to GP, 111 & ambulance services, which affects the whole  population, will have the greatest impact on people who even in better times,  tend to present late in their illness. The window for effective treatment is narrower.

You are right that there is no evidence for a widespread medical conspiracy against disabled people, nor is it about access to cardio-respiratory resuscitation because by the time anyone is so ill they need that, the odds are heavily against them.

CIPOLD classed 48% of deaths of people with learning disabilities as avoidable. Subdivided -  12% preventable by public health measures & 28% amenable to better access. 9% both amenable & preventable. So better access & understanding how treatable conditions are missed important. https://t.co/AZlaOtgPDx

Health professionals may not recognise that what they are told means that person is sick. They may see the long term impairment but not the acute illness (diagnostic overshadowing). These things happen without intentional malice.

There are other reasons disabled people, including people with learning disabilities  do not always get good timely treatment. It may take them & those close to them longer to recognise the illness or that it is serious.

This is indeed misinformation about value of resuscitation which is seldom life saving. But assumptions about the quality of disabled peoples lives can limit their access to treatments that really might be life saving. https://t.co/P8sXYAyjGq

The histories of those times, most of all from the people with learning disabilities who lived them, must be heard. Creative people, with & without learning disabilities, need to take those stories, & make them accessible & interesting to wider audiences.

There were bad bits too. Times when I could see no alternative to admitting a person to hospital, even though it probably wasn't the right place for them.  Hearing about being teased & bullied in the street. Witnessing restrictions on peoples lives in hostels, care homes, at home

Working alongside research/training advisors like Gary Butler, Jackie Downer & Wendy Perez. With @osraj1  @BaronessHollins  & others developing employment of actors with learning disabilities as simulated patients in student exams.

Why did society - all of us, allow those bad things to happen? I was interested because I suppose I was a tiny part of that history: at @StGeorgesUni involving Strathcona & Baked Bean Theatre Companies in teaching Medical Students how to communicate.

In that time bad things happened too. Some people were abused, in hospitals, in care homes, & when living in their own homes. People in Adult Training Centres used to do real work & were paid - not much. The Day Centres that came later did art, craft, games, jigsaws - but no pay

An important start to discussions about how things have  & haven't changed for people with learning disabilities in the last 50 years. When the change was positive, how did that happen? What social movements were involved? https://t.co/CgHU8HuZQE
